title: Converted Warehouse in London’s Covent Garden on the Market for £3.5M
text:
A townhouse in London’s Covent Garden that used to belong to Blur bassist Alex James is on the market asking £3.5 million (US$4.3 million).



The Grade II-listed brick and timber building was home to the Britpop star—who now is a cheesemaker—during the late 1990s and early 2000s, until he sold it in 2004 for £1.5 million, listing records show. It hit the market in early September.



More: Two-Bedroom Apartment in London’s Mayfair to Rent for £30,000 Per Month

“It's unusual to find an entire freehold house in Covent Garden,” said Jamie Read, director at listing agency Tavistock Bow, in a news release, “especially one with such a rich history as this: a beautiful building, unique and full of character, but with everything you'd expect of a modern London home.”



“The location is fantastic, right in the heart of the action, but discreet and quiet. It really is a complete one-off,” Mr. Read said.



The five-story converted warehouse is in the Sevendials area of the Covent Garden neighborhood, an enclave surrounding a junction where seven streets join at a central column adorned with six sundials.



In the 1830s, Charles Dickens wrote of Sevendials, “Where is there such another maze of streets, courts, lanes, and alleys? Where such a pure mixture of Englishmen and Irishmen, as in this complicated part of London?”



From Penta: English Soccer Star John Terry Buys £4.35 Million Country Manor

The two-bedroom townhouse has beamed ceilings, wooden floors, a top-floor master bedroom, a guest bedroom, a dressing room, a living room with a balcony, a study and a dining room, according to the listing.



The property was remodeled by architect Sir Terry Farrell between 1983 and 1985. Mr. Farrell’s other notable projects in the city include Camden Lock and the MI6 Headquarters at Vauxhall.



The current owner is a limited company registered in the Cayman Islands, property records show. They paid £2.25 million for the property in 2009.



Since Blur’s heyday, Mr. James, 50, has become an award-winning cheesemaker, and holds an annual music and food festival dubbed “The Big Feastival” on his 200-acre Cotswolds farm. He could not be reached for comment.
